title: Frankie de la Cruz
text:
Eulogio "Frankie" De La Cruz Martínez (;) (March 12, 1984 – March 14, 2021) was a Dominican <a href="baseball">baseball</a> <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> who played four seasons in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB), as well as one season each in <a href="Nippon%20Professional%20Baseball">Nippon Professional Baseball</a> (NPB) and the <a href="Chinese%20Professional%20Baseball%20League">Chinese Professional Baseball League</a> (CPBL). He played for the <a href="Detroit%20Tigers">Detroit Tigers</a>, <a href="Florida%20Marlins">Florida Marlins</a>, <a href="San%20Diego%20Padres">San Diego Padres</a>, <a href="Milwaukee%20Brewers">Milwaukee Brewers</a>, <a href="Tokyo%20Yakult%20Swallows">Tokyo Yakult Swallows</a>, and <a href="Uni-President%207-Eleven%20Lions">Uni-President 7-Eleven Lions</a> from 2007 to 2012. He went on to play baseball in Italy and Mexico, as well as several winter leagues.
Early life.
De La Cruz was born in <a href="Santo%20Domingo">Santo Domingo</a>, <a href="Dominican%20Republic">Dominican Republic</a>, on March 12, 1984. He attended <a href="Juan%20Pablo%20Duarte%20High%20School">Juan Pablo Duarte High School</a> in his hometown. He was signed as an amateur free agent by the <a href="Detroit%20Tigers">Detroit Tigers</a> on September 6, 2001.
Professional career.
Minor leagues.
De La Cruz played in Rookie ball and Single-A from 2002 through 2004. He played for the Advanced Single-A <a href="Lakeland%20Tigers">Lakeland Tigers</a> and in Double-A in 2006. The following year, he went 5–6 with a 3.43 <a href="Earned%20run%20average">ERA</a> with the Double-A <a href="Erie%20SeaWolves">Erie SeaWolves</a> and 0–0 in innings with an 11.57 ERA with the Triple-A <a href="Toledo%20Mud%20Hens">Toledo Mud Hens</a>.
Detroit Tigers.
De La Cruz made his MLB debut on June 18, 2007, at the age of 23, relieving <a href="Jason%20Grilli">Jason Grilli</a> and pitching one scoreless inning in a 9–8 win over the <a href="Washington%20Nationals">Washington Nationals</a>. Overall, he finished his first season in the major leagues with a 6.75 <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a> (ERA) and 5 <a href="strikeout">strikeout</a>s in innings pitched. At the end of the year, the Tigers traded Cruz along with <a href="Andrew%20Miller%20%28baseball%29">Andrew Miller</a>, <a href="Cameron%20Maybin">Cameron Maybin</a>, <a href="Mike%20Rabelo">Mike Rabelo</a>, <a href="Dallas%20Trahern">Dallas Trahern</a>, and <a href="Burke%20Badenhop">Burke Badenhop</a> to the <a href="Florida%20Marlins">Florida Marlins</a> for <a href="Dontrelle%20Willis">Dontrelle Willis</a> and <a href="Miguel%20Cabrera">Miguel Cabrera</a>.
Florida Marlins.
De La Cruz spent the majority of the 2008 season with the Triple-A <a href="Albuquerque%20Isotopes">Albuquerque Isotopes</a>. He compiled an 18.00 ERA, 4 strikeouts, and 11 <a href="Base%20on%20balls">walks</a> in 9 innings pitched on the major league roster. During his only career <a href="Games%20started">start</a> in the second game of a <a href="Doubleheader%20%28baseball%29">doubleheader</a> against the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Giants">San Francisco Giants</a> on May 25, he surrendered two <a href="earned%20run">earned run</a>s across three innings pitched.
San Diego Padres.
The <a href="San%20Diego%20Padres">San Diego Padres</a> acquired De La Cruz on March 25, 2009, for a player to be named later or cash from the Marlins. Just over a month later, he was designated for assignment after three <a href="games%20pitched">games pitched</a> (5.40 ERA in innings) and outrighted to the Triple-A <a href="Portland%20Beavers">Portland Beavers</a>. He was later released by the Padres at the end of the year.
Tokyo Yakult Swallows.
De La Cruz signed with the <a href="Tokyo%20Yakult%20Swallows">Tokyo Yakult Swallows</a> of <a href="Nippon%20Professional%20Baseball">Nippon Professional Baseball</a> for the 2010 season. He had a 2–3 record, a 2.52 ERA, and 42 strikeouts across innings in the minor league <a href="Eastern%20League%20%28Japanese%20baseball%29">Eastern League</a>. He was subsequently promoted to the major league roster and compiled a 7.84 ERA in nine games. He became a free agent after the season.
Milwaukee Brewers.
De La Cruz signed a minor league contract with the <a href="Milwaukee%20Brewers">Milwaukee Brewers</a> on January 12, 2011. Eight months later, he was promoted to the major league roster after spending most of the season with the Triple-A <a href="Nashville%20Sounds">Nashville Sounds</a>. De La Cruz registered a 2.77 ERA with 9 strikeouts in 13 innings pitched for the Brewers that year.
Chicago Cubs.
De La Cruz was claimed off waivers by the <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a> on March 16, 2012. He was subsequently outrighted to the Triple-A <a href="Iowa%20Cubs">Iowa Cubs</a> one month later. He was released on August 14 that year, enabling him to sign with a Chinese Professional Baseball team.
Uni-President 7-Eleven Lions.
After being released by the Cubs, De La Cruz signed with the <a href="Uni-President%207-Eleven%20Lions">Uni-President 7-Eleven Lions</a> of the <a href="Chinese%20Professional%20Baseball%20League">Chinese Professional Baseball League</a>. De La Cruz pitched to a 2.00 ERA with 29 strikeouts in 36 innings pitched for the Lions across 6 appearances.
Second stint with Brewers.
De La Cruz signed a minor league deal with the <a href="Milwaukee%20Brewers">Milwaukee Brewers</a> on November 16, 2012. He had a combined 3–11 record, a 6.52 ERA, and 65 strikeouts with the <a href="Huntsville%20Stars">Huntsville Stars</a> and <a href="Nashville%20Sounds">Nashville Sounds</a> in 2013. He became a free agent at the end of the season.
Later career.
De La Cruz signed with the <a href="Sultanes%20de%20Monterrey">Sultanes de Monterrey</a> of the <a href="Mexican%20Baseball%20League">Mexican Baseball League</a> (LMB) on April 3, 2014. He pitched three months with the team, during which he compiled a 4–3 record, a 3.67 ERA, and 37 strikeouts, before being released at the end of June. He went on to play in winter leagues in his <a href="Dominican%20Professional%20Baseball%20League">home country</a>, <a href="Mexican%20Pacific%20League">Mexico</a>, and <a href="Venezuelan%20Professional%20Baseball%20League">Venezuela</a> during the rest of 2014 and in 2015.
De La Cruz signed with the <a href="Nettuno%20Baseball%20City">Nettuno Baseball City</a> of the <a href="Italian%20Baseball%20League">Italian Baseball League</a> for the 2016 season. He had a 3–4 record, a 2.65 ERA, and 56 strikeouts in 68 innings pitched. He returned to the LMB the following year, signing with the <a href="Saraperos%20de%20Saltillo">Saraperos de Saltillo</a> at the end of March 2017. In his two seasons with the team, he compiled a 14–12 record and 158 strikeouts in innings pitched. He was released in mid-July 2018, and consequently signed with the <a href="Diablos%20Rojos%20del%20M%C3%A9xico">Diablos Rojos del México</a>. He went 3–1 with a 4.65 ERA and 17 strikeouts in six games.
De La Cruz signed with the <a href="Algodoneros%20de%20Uni%C3%B3n%20Laguna">Algodoneros de Unión Laguna</a> of the <a href="Mexican%20League">Mexican League</a> on April 6, 2019. He had a 6–6 record, a 4.91 ERA, and 92 strikeouts across innings pitched that season. He did not play for the club in 2020, due to the cancellation of the LMB season as a result of the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>. He played for <a href="Toros%20del%20Este">Toros del Este</a> in the Dominican Winter League from November to December 2020, his second stint with the team.
Later life.
De La Cruz died on the night of March 14, 2021, two days after his 37th birthday. He suffered a heart attack prior to his death.
